message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The finding on sialometry suggests a lesion of the glossopharyngeal nerve, which also serves as the afferent limb of the gag reflex. None of the other options are related to the glossopharyngeal nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question is asking for the nerve responsible for decreased saliva production from the left parotid gland. Among the options, only the afferent limb of the gag reflex, which is mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve, innervates the parotid gland, hence it is the correct answer. Protrusion of the tongue is controlled by the hypoglossal nerve, afferent limb of the cough reflex is mediated by the vagus nerve, and equilibrium and balance are regulated by the vestibulocochlear nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve that is responsible for both the parotid gland function and the afferent limb of the gag reflex is the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). None of the other options are associated with this nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve responsible for the parotid gland and the efferent limb of the gag reflex is the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). Lesion of this nerve can cause decreased saliva production from the parotid gland and impaired gag reflex.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lesion of the nerve that is responsible for the decreased saliva production from the left parotid gland is the glossopharyngeal nerve. This nerve is also responsible for the afferent limb of the gag reflex. Protrusion of the tongue is controlled by the hypoglossal nerve, the afferent limb of the cough reflex is controlled by the vagus nerve, and equilibrium and balance are controlled by the vestibulocochlear nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decreased production of saliva from the left parotid gland suggests a lesion of the facial nerve, which is also responsible for the afferent limb of the gag reflex. The other options are not related to the facial nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The parotid salivary gland is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for the afferent limb of the gag reflex. The other options are not related to the glossopharyngeal nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The parotid gland is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for the afferent limb of the gag reflex. Lesions of the glossopharyngeal nerve can cause decreased saliva production and impaired gag reflex.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve responsible for both the decreased production of saliva from the left parotid gland and the afferent limb of the gag reflex is the glossopharyngeal nerve. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) the afferent limb of the gag reflex. The other options are controlled by different nerves - the hypoglossal nerve for protrusion of the tongue, the vagus nerve for the afferent limb of the cough reflex, and the vestibulocochlear nerve for equilibrium and balance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The parotid gland is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for the afferent limb of the gag reflex. Lesion of this nerve can lead to decreased salivary production and impaired gag reflex. Protrusion of the tongue is innervated by the hypoglossal nerve, afferent limb of the cough reflex is innervated by the vagus nerve, and equilibrium and balance are controlled by the inner ear and vestibulocochlear nerve.
